root.pub-comments: This is the first presentation of the Sepik-Ramu phylum. The interrelatedness of the languages in the phylum has not been fully demonstrated, and there are areas of this tree that can be considered significantly doubtful. The Sepik-Ramu phylum is so large, it is difficult to find features that are relatively stable throughout the entire group. Phonology offers some common features: nearly all Sepik-Ramu languages have a restricted vowel inventory, the consonants /p t k/ (with voiceless, unaspirated, voiced, and nasal variants). Grammatically, there is less crossover between languages. Most of the languages show a dual-classifying system, though some languages in the Upper Sepik area, under the influence of Torricelli languages, sometimes have multiple-classifying systems. (Laycock 1973: 19-20) Population numbers in this tree are accurate to 1 January 1970.

child.pub-comments: Laycock writes that the Ramu Sub-Phylum extends deep into the Madang District. The languages he lists in this book are only found in the East Sepik District, and Laycock implores readers to consult Z'graggen (1971) for more information about Ramu languages not limited to the East Sepik District.
"The Annaberg Stock is called 'Annaberg group' by Z'graggen (1971), but it seems possible to regard it as a stock on the basis of Z'graggen's own data." (Laycock 1973: 40)
Population: 450. See Z'graggen (1971) for more information.
child.geography: Asapi, Atsuvatapi, Diugumbi, Ivagripi, Ivarapi, Iwam, Uliangupi, Vavapi
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: "The languages of the Grass Stock show clear interrelationship on all levels; only Banaro is lexically aberrant, and is placed therefore in a separate family. Typologically the languages are simple; number marking in nouns absent or regular, person marking in verbs absent, no noun-classification; gender distinction in third singular pronouns only. Tense/aspect is usually shown in verbs by particles (preceding the following), less often by affixation. There is no evidence of a dual number." (Laycock 1973: 38)
Population: 774. Laycock asserts that it is apparent that Aion is closely related to Kambot, Adjora, and Gorovu, in contrast to earlier analyses by Z'graggen (1971: 88). (Laycock 1973: 39)
child.geography: Agrant, Akaian, Angang, Arango, Ombos, Oremai, Pankin

child.pub-comments: Population: 50. Laycock writes that the former village of Govoru merged with Bangapella. The merging of these villages, according to Z'graggen (1971:877), may lead to the eventual extinction of Govoru, as the newly combined village of Bangapella is primarily Banaro speaking. (Laycock 1973: 38)

child.pub-comments: Population 2569. Laycock suggests that Banara belongs with other languages in the Grass Stock, as opposed to the analysis by Z'graggen (1971: 85). Laycock also notes that the villages of Bugaram and Ninias speak vastly different dialects. (Laycock 1973: 39)

child.pub-comments: "The three languages of this stock/family show close lexical similarities, including the pronouns, with the languages of the Grass Stock, but have in addition some pluralization in nouns (like the Nor-Pondo and Yuat languages) and a great deal of lexical resemblance to Yuat languages. They clearly form a separate stock within the Ramu Sub-Phylum, though it is possible they belong rather inside the Ramu Super-Stock than outside it." (Laycock 1973: 36)
Population: 814.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: "The Yuat stock/family consists of five closely interrelated languages spoken in the vicinity of the Yuat River. Typologically and lexically, the languages show elements from both Grass Stock languages and Nor-Pondo languages; there are also many lexical items from Sepik Hill languages. Plural marking is present in nouns, but this tends to be phonologically predictable; there is no evidence of noun classification, or of person-marking in verbs. As is the case with the Mongol-Langam stock/family, it is possible that further research will show that these languages should be included with the Ramu Super-Stock." (Laycock 1973: 36-37)
Population: 194. Laycock notes that Bun is almost "but not quite" a dialect of Biwat. (Laycock 1973: 37)

child.pub-comments: The Ndu family is distinguished from other members of the Middle Sepik subgroup (stock) by having separate pronouns for second person, feminine. (Laycock 1973: 24)

child.alt-names: Big Sepik, No.2 Sepik, Middle Sepik
child.pub-comments: Population: 9842. See Laycock (1965) for more information. This language has two dialects: Nyaura (Nyawra) and Palimbei. (Laycock 1973: 26-27)

child.pub-comments: Population: 9005. "No real dialect surveys have been undertaken, and there may be at least two distinct languages subsumed under Sawos, though there is no doubt that all villages listed speak languages that are part of the Ndu Family. Glasgow and Loving (1964) give dialect indications for those Sepik Plains languages spoken in the Maprik subdistrict; combining these indications with those of Laycock, we get the following dialects: East, Central, Chimbian, Koiwat, West, and Burui." (Laycock 1973: 27-28

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.geography: Balmo, Chuinimbu, Kwaliangwa, Sotangai, Timbunangua, Wairaman, Kamaragu, Makambu, Pangiembit, Jiginumbut, Kingaui, Malimbo, Manganjangut, Simangaui, Suimbo, Tinboli, Yindigum, Nagotimbi, Gaikarobi

child.pub-comments: Population: 100. Laycock reports that there is no data on this language, but it is reported that inhabitants of this village speak a language similar to Sawos, and certainly another Ndu language. (Laycock 1973: 28)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 136. See Laycock (1965a), Laycock (1968: 52), and Newton (1971) for more information. Laycock notes that 'Nggala' is the preferable spelling for this language name, but that 'Ngala' is the established convention. (Laycock 1973: 28)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 70. See Laycock (1965a) and Laycock (1968: 51) for more details. Speakers are reported to be bilingual in Kwoma. (Laycock 1973: 28)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 2058. See Laycock (1968) and Allen and Hurd (1972) for more information. "The SIL team of R. and M. Farnsworth have further unpublished material on Manumbu. They state…that the village of Sengo is reported to speak the same language, but are not sure. Otherwise, Sengo will speak a Sepik Plains dialect." (Laycock 1973: 27)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.alt-names: Gawanga, Mende, Nihamber Sambu, Seim, Womsak
child.pub-comments: Population: 13305. See Laycock (1968: 54-55) for more information. This language has five major dialects: Yubanakor, Bongamaise, Apos, Bongos, and Tau. Seim may also constitute a dialect of this language, and is sometimes listed as a separate language all together. (Laycock 1973: 24)
In Laycock (1968), Seim is listed as a separate language to Kwanga, but it is now known to be only a dialect. (Laycock 1973: 24)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 390. Laycock notes that several reports suggest that Yerakai is more closely related to the Ndu languages than other Yerakai languages. Laycock, however, places this language in this family due to its lack of feminine second-person pronouns, a feature also observed in the other languages of this subgroup. (Laycock 1973: 23)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 2925. See Laycock (1968: 53) for more information.
child.geography: Bangwis, Beglam, Melawei, Saseriman, Tongwinjamb, Urambanj, Waskuk, Ablatak, Amaki, Ambuken, Kawaka, Kwakauru, Nageri
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Laycock writes that there seems to be an argument for splitting the Sepik Hill stock into at least two families: one of the southern languages Setiali, Gabiano, and Hewa, the other of all remaining Sepik Hill languages. There also seems to be some evidence of an east-west divide between the Sepik Hill languages, but evidence available at the time of writing made it impossible to confidently assert such an idea, thus accounting for its exclusion in this book. (Laycock 1973: 28)
Please see note for Sepik Hill Stock.
Population: 160. See Dye and Townsends (1969) for more information.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 178. All information on this language, at the writing of this paper, came from Dye and Townsends (1969). Laycock notes that the village list is likely incomplete, due to the village's lack of being censused before 1973 at the writing of this paper. (Laycock 1973: 30)
child.geography: Bayamo, Bitara, Kagiru, Pegi, Pisi, Yanaut
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 433. See Dye and Townsends (1969) and Newton (1971) for more information.
child.geography: Bugiaui, Inaro, Moli, Gahom, Namu, Wagu No.2, Yigei
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 644. "An SIL team (R. and S. Lewis) is working in the language, and has published two papers (R. Lewis (1972), S. Lewis (1972)). They call the language Sanio-Hiowe. According to my data, the term Sanio is used only for the western group, living in the areas between the Wogumas and Leonhard Schultze rivers, while Hiowe is used for the remaining population in the Wogumas and April river area, so the hyphenated term may well be justified. However, it does not seem inappropriate to extend a restricted term to embrace the whole language, in the same way that the language spoken in Australia and America is still referred to as 'English'." (Laycock 1973: 30)
child.geography: Begapuki, Lariaso, Nabisi, Nakek, Nekiei, Saurinapi, Sio, Sowano, Tauanapi, Waurinapi, Yabatauwe
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 200.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 1500. See Steadman (1971), Dye and Townsends (1969), and Cochran (1968) for more information.
child.geography: Morobanmin, Remban, Yoliapi, and other settlements in the Western Highlands District.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 65. See Dye and Townsends (1969) for more information. Laycock notes that the town of Sumariup used to be known as Latoma. (Laycock 1973: 29)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: ?. See Dye and Townsends (1969) for more data. A wordlist from L. Gragge corroborates Dye and Townsends' inclusion of Piame as a Sepik Hill language. (Laycock 1973: 31)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 98. See Dye and Townsends (1969) for more information. According to L. Bragge, this language appears to be spoken in Kabian, a village/hamlet south of Setiali.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 1439.
child.geography: Bugumute, Kabriman, Kraimbit, Kuvenmas, Sangriman, Tungambit, Yesimbit
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: ?. "Patrol Report 4/70-71 of Ambunti (L. Bragge) gives a wordlist in a language called Bikaru, spoken around the Eastern April river headwaters; from patrol reports from Amboin, the same language apparently extends to the headwaters of the Salumei River. From the wordlist given, it is not quite clear whether the language belongs with the Western Highlands Stock or with the Sepik Hill Family; however, it shows a number of good Sepik Hill cognates...and does not appear to resemble nearby Highlands languages (Bisorio or Enga). Bikaru is therefore tentatively classified with Sepik Hill, pending further data." (Laycock 1973: 32)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 359. Please see Dye and Townsends (1969) for more information. (Laycock 1973: 29)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 120. Dye and Townsends (1969) reports a population of 147, suggesting that this language may be spoken in uncensused hamlets in the area around Mari. (Laycock 1973: 29)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 1107. Data from Dye and Townsends (1969: 147) suggest that Angamei, Sevenbuk, and Tarakai villages speak a different dialect from the rest of the villages speaking the Alamblak language. (Laycock 1973: 29)
child.geography: Amongabi, Barapidjin, Chimbut, Danyig, Maranba, Marianmei, Meingenda, Sikaium, Yenitabak, Anganmei, Sevenbuk, Tarakai
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 395. See Dye and Townsends (1969) for more information.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: ?. A wordlist compiled by L. Bragge in 1970-1971 suggests that Paka may be a dialect of Setiali. This language appears to be spoken in Sumwari, Yaramui No.1, Yaramui No.2, and Paka, though due to lack of census data, nothing definitive could be written. (Laycock 1973: 31)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 187. Laycock exhibits doubt over whether this language should be included with this family or in the Tama family of his Tama stock. He notes, however, that Chenapian is typologically close to Wogamusin. (Laycock 1973: 21)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 44. See Laycock (1968: 37) for more information.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 520. See Laycock (1968: 35) for more information.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 4545. See Laycock (1965b) for phonology. This language exhibits tonal contrasts, but cannot be regarded as fully tonal. (Laycock 1973: 21)
child.geography: Abaru, Dieru, Iburu, Minaburu, Ogru, Simia, Baiuwai, Baio, Biake No.1, Biake No.2, Buna, Hifi, Iaburu, Idam No.1, Idam No.2, Ileis, Imnai, Isu, Kaseiru, Kobararu, Maha, Mahani, Musuasi, Sereian, Waiar, Wauru, Yaseiru, Beimap, Wagu No.1, Weidoru, Buriap, Yabal, possibly 6 other villages in the West Irain area.

Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 388. See Laycock (1968) for a wordlist.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 3197. For an overview of the phonology of Iwam, see Laycock (1965b). Other research has been completed by the SIL team R. and J Conrad, and J. Rehburg and M. Laszlo. There are two dialects: downriver and upriver. (Laycock 1973: 21)

child.geography: Oum No.1, Oum No.2, Tauri, Yauenian, Auni, Iniok

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 200? "A previously unrecorded language, spoken in unlocated villages towards the headwaters of the Biake River, west of the international border near Green River. The language appears to show distant connection with languages of the Middle Sepik Super-Stock, especially in lexicon and pronouns; but does not closely resemble any other language in the area. It is here classified tentatively, therefore, as a stock-level isolate within the Sepik Sub-Phylum." (Laycock 1973: 20)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 599. "Work in progress by SIL team V. Foreman and H. Marten, stationed at Maio. All villages except Maio and Yessan speak a different dialect, called Warasai in Laycock (1968: 41), but preferably known as Yau. See also Newton (1971) for cultural details." (Laycock 1973: 22)
The name Yau is preferably to Warasai. (Laycock 1973: 22)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.geography: Maio, Yessan, Asawur, Nau'ali, Yaunget, Warasai, Alkai
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 161. Laycock notes that this language is very close to Mayo, especially the Yau dialect. (Laycock 1973: 22)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 3012. See Laycock (1968: 56) for more information.
child.geography: Aiendami, Akwom, Alai, Ameni, Gwidami, Iwani, Manitopai, Nami, Naum, Norambalip, Pabei, Worikori, Yawari, Yegarapi, Panewai, Tipa
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 83. "Villagers in Kwieftim village claim that they are fully bilingual in Fas, and that they can interpret in Yis, Bouye, and Namie." (Laycock 1973: 23)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 384. See Laycock (1968: 61) for more information.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 544. This language is closely related to Pasi, but is not a dialect of it. (Laycock 1973: 22)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 3336. See Laycock (1968: 39) for more information.
child.geography: Ifkindu, Klaplei No.1, Klaplei No.2, Klaplei No.3, Mantsuku, Nuku, Wilwil, Yiminim
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 820. The village of Yimin does not speak Kalou, but rather Pasi. (Laycock 1973: 23)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: The Nor-Pondo group was first proposed by Laumann (1951) and confirmed (and developed) by Haberland (1966). Typological features seem to contradict other languages in the Sepik-Ramu Phylum, but the lexicon and phonology of these languages resemble that of the Ramu Super-Stock fairly closely. (Laycock 1973: 33)

Population: 6514. Laycock notes that the villages of Bien, Imbuando, and Marbuk speak a dialect different from the other villages listed, but this dialect is not named. He also notes that there is other clear dialectal variance that has not yet been mapped or thoroughly researched. (Laycock 1973: 34)
child.geography: Angoram, Kambrindo, Kambrok, Kanuanum, Krinjambi, Magendo, Moim, Mundomundo, Pinang, Timabli, Yueriman, Agrumara, Andua, Arangunam, Kausimbi, Kundima, Maramba, Sapalu, Chuimondo, Bien, Imbuando, Marbuk
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 1050. "Grammatically the most complex of the Nor-Pondo languages, with multiple noun-classes and agreements for class in singular, dual and plural in all numerals, possessive pronouns, adjectives, and some verb forms; worthy of much more detailed study." (Laycock 1973: 35)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 200. See Haberland (1966) for more information.
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 1300. See Dye and Townsends (1969) and Haberland (1966) for more information.
child.geography: Ambonwari, Kaiwaria, Konmei, Kundiman, Kungriambun, Manjamai, Marinyam, Masandenai, Meikerobi
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 1476. In early descriptions of the language by Schmidt (1953) and Schmidt (1924-26, 1933), a noun-classification system is detailed. Laycock, however, found no such evidence of a system, suggesting that speakers either simplified the language during elicitation or that younger speakers entirely abandoned the noun-classification system. Verbs, Laycock notes, do show several complex features, also observed in other languages of this group. (Laycock 1973: 33-34)
child.geography: Aramut, Darapap, Jangimut, Karau, Kaup, Mendam, Wagamut
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 229. Laycock notes that there seems to be some "insignificant" dialect difference between the Kopar spoken in the villages of Kopar and Wongun. (Laycock 1973: 34)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 75. "Papi (the indigenous pronunciation of the village is here used as the language name) is spoken only in one small village on the Frieda River." (Laycock 1973: 33)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 74. "Informants claimed a difference in men and women's speech in Gapun, but a quick check on this showed only a few lexical differences, and a small difference in verb morphology. Further testing may show a greater difference. Most Gapun speakers appear to be able to speak also Watam and Angoram." (Laycock 1973: 35)
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841

child.pub-comments: Population: 2451. Laycock notes that the village of Terebu (Turupu) originally spoke Kaiep, but is now primarily Bungain speaking, which has led to some confusion in scholarly works. (Laycock 1973: 35-36)
child.geography: Bungain, Dagawat, Forok No.1, Forok No.2, Haregin, Kandai, Mundungai, Munjun, Musangun, Namareb, Sil/Sigan, Sinambila, Suanum, Taul, Terebu, Wiabab, Wawat No.1, Wawat No.2, Yaugiba
child.publications: Laycock, Donald C. 1973. Sepik Languages- Checklist and Preliminary Classification. Canberra, Australia: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858830841
